reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s reliance (especially in §3–§3.5) on fairly stable utility/axiology “shape” distinctions (linear vs diminishing, bounded vs unbounded) when assessing whether bargaining/trade can yield mostly-great futures. If those descriptors become strategically endogenized under mind-copying and identity-engineering, that would be a real additional blocker to the optimism about trade/compromise and could exacerbate power-concentration/decision-procedure fragility—so the attacked point is moderately central. However, the essay is mostly conditional and already emphasizes institutional dependence, timing effects (quasi-linear becoming linear after satiation), and blockers; it does not straightforwardly propose building protocols around inferred curvature, so the critique partially mis-aims at an extrapolated institutionalization rather than the essay’s core conclusions. The scenario is conceptually plausible (preference manipulation via identity splits; dynamic inconsistency; legitimacy crises), but the predicted cascade (perpetual renegotiation → emergency decree) is speculative and not tightly argued. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little non-contributing material.
title: Programmable identities make utility curvature manipulable, breaking curvature-based bargaining protocols
